'''Alan Thomas Grieve''', [[CBE]] (born 22 January 1928<ref>{{cite journal | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Birthdays | journal = The Guardian | volume = | issue = | pages = 33 | publisher = Guardian News & Media | location = London | date = 22 January 2014 | language = | url = | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm =}}</ref> in London, England) is a lawyer, company director and chairman of the [[Jerwood Foundation]].
Alan Grieve was educated at [[Aldenham School]] and [[Trinity Hall, Cambridge]]. He undertook [[National Service]] and was commissioned in 1949 in the [[Royal Armoured Corps]];<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=38639 |supp=y|page=2942 |date=14 June 1949}}</ref> he subsequently served as a [[Army Reserve (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] officer in the [[City of London Yeomanry (Rough Riders)]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=40270 |supp=y|page=5127 |date=3 September 1954}}</ref> He joined the [[Gray's Inn]] solicitors Taylor & Humbert in 1958 after gaining commercial, city and merger and acquisition experience as an assistant solicitor at [[Slaughter and May]]. He became senior partner of Taylor & Humbert in 1980. During those 22 years the firms expanded as a commercial and private client practice and established Interlex, an international grouping of lawyers.
Grieve organised and managed the merger of Taylor & Humbert with the City firm of Parker Garrett and the merged firm was renamed Taylor Garrett where Grieve remained the Senior Partner until 1989 when Taylor Garrett merged with Joynson Hicks to become Taylor Joynson Garrett. Grieve remained a consultant to the enlarged firm which is now [[Taylor Wessing]].
Grieve established the Jerwood Foundation for his client, [[John Jerwood]], in 1977 and has been running it as chairman since Jerwood's death in 1991, responsible for the distribution of some ₤90 million in funding for the arts in Britain, as well as for accumulating the foundation's art collection now on display at the [[Jerwood Gallery]] at [[Hastings]].<ref name="Indy">Simon Tait, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/alan-grieve-is-the-future-of-the-arts-in-his-hands-a-serial-giver-owns-up-7554164.html "Alan Grieve: Is the future of the arts in his hands? A serial giver owns up"], ''[[The Independent]]'', 11 March 2012.</ref> He was honoured with a [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] for services to the arts, in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Alan Grieve Esq., CBE |work=People of Today |publisher=Debretts |date= |url=http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/g/18581/Alan%20Thomas+GRIEVE.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130215214841/http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/g/18581/Alan%20Thomas+GRIEVE.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 February 2013 |format= |doi= |accessdate=22 January 2014 }}</ref>
Grieve has five children; his eldest daughter is [[Amanda Harlech]],<ref>Caroline Scott, [http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/Magazine/relative_values/article1058832.ece "She was spoilt, privileged and drove guys potty"], ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', 17 June 2012.</ref> Charles Grieve is managing director of Brandcast Media, Lara Wardle is Director of the Jerwood Foundation and Tom Grieve is the architect<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hatprojects.com/tom.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-01-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005093008/http://hatprojects.com/tom.html |archive-date=2013-10-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> responsible for the new Jerwood Gallery.<ref name="Indy"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.jerwoodfoundation.org/about Profile] at [[Jerwood Foundation]] official website *[https://archive.is/20140403171517/http://www.ingramcollection.com/how-to-get-a-head-in-sculpture-my-tiring-life-as-a-model/ article The Times 23.9.13; Grieve portrait part of Sculpture Series Heads exhibited at Yorkshire Sculpture Park]

'''Billy Bridges''' (born 22 March 1984) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[ice sledge hockey]] and [[wheelchair basketball]] player. Born in [[Summerside, Prince Edward Island|Summerside]], he has [[spina bifida]]. On July 1, 2011, Bridges married former Olympic women's ice hockey player [[Sami Jo Small]].
He began playing ice sledge hockey in 1997, aged 12, for the Kitchener Sidewinders. Aged 14, he was selected for Canada's national team, the youngest player ever to be picked. He has World Championship golds from 2000, 2008, 2013 and 2017 and Paralympic gold from 2006,<ref>{{cite news |title=Team Canada wins gold in sledge hockey, wheelchair curling |work=[[Toronto Star]] |date=March 19, 2006 |at=Sports section, p. 8 }}</ref> where he was picked for the All-Star Team.
As well as ice sledge hockey, he has a career as a wheelchair basketball player, including seven Canadian titles with Team Ontario. In 2001, he also competed at the Junior World Championships, and in 2005 was selected as the team's most valuable player (MVP).

{{for|the music group|Captain Chaos (band)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox character | colour = #840007 | name = Captain Chaos | image = Captain_Chaos.jpg | caption = Dom DeLuise as Captain Chaos | creator = {{Plainlist| * [[Brock Yates]] }} | portrayer = [[Dom DeLuise]] | voice = [[Dom DeLuise]] | gender = [[Male]] | occupation = {{Plainlist| * Mechanic * Adventurer * Hero }} | spouse = | children = | relatives = }}
'''Captain Chaos''' is a [[fictional character]] in the [[The Cannonball Run|Cannonball Run]] movie series. He is the [[alter-ego]] of mild-mannered mechanic Victor Prinzim ([[Dom DeLuise]]).
Victor is soft-spoken and unpretentious, but when situations arise that he himself is too timid to handle, Victor is compelled to don his satin cape and cowl and becomes the heroic Captain Chaos.
Psychiatrists have diagnosed Victor as having [[multiple personality disorder]], but Victor himself is convinced that he channels the spirit of an actual living [[superhero]] who always manages to arrive just in time to save the day.<ref name="Book 1">{{cite book | title=VideoHound's dragon: Asian action & cult flicks | publisher=Visible Ink Press | author=Brian Thomas | year=2003 | isbn=1-57859-141-4}}</ref><ref name="Book2">{{cite book | title=Hick flicks: the rise and fall of redneck cinema | publisher=McFarland, | author=Scott Von Doviak | year=2005 | pages=113 | isbn=0-7864-1997-0}}</ref><ref name="Book 3">{{cite book | title=Cannonball! | publisher=MotorBooks International | author=Brock Yates | year=2003 | pages=262 | isbn=0-7603-1633-3}}</ref><ref name="Book 5">{{cite book | title=One hundred road movies | publisher=BFI | author=Jason Wood | year=2007 | pages=31 | isbn=1-84457-160-2}}</ref>
Author David Quinlan wrote of ''Cannonball Run'' in ''The TV Times Film and Video Guide'', stating {{sic}} "The best thing in the film is Dom DeLuise who, as the schizophrenic Victor, turns moments of stress into tubby superhero Captain Chaos!"<ref name="Book 4">{{cite book | title=The TV Times Film and Video Guide | publisher=Batsford | author=David Quinlan | year=1998 | pages=116 | isbn=0-7134-8443-8}}</ref>
==Characteristics== Captain Chaos' costume (which Victor puts on over whatever he happens to be wearing at the time) is a long flowing orange satin cape and matching cowl with an attached black [[domino mask]], and the word "chaos" written in white across the cowl's forehead (in the [[Cannonball Run II|sequel film]] the cape and cowl are red). After Victor transforms into Captain Chaos, he speaks in a slightly lower voice register with [[basso profondo]] inflections similar to that of a typical cartoon superhero. His appearance is invariably prefaced by the vocal fanfare ''"Dunn dun DU-UH-UHNNNN!!''", to approximate Chaos' theme music.
==''"...Him."''== Most people who meet Victor are somewhat bewildered at the eventual emergence of his alter ego of Captain Chaos, whose heroism and courage are in stark contrast to Victor's milquetoast personality. Though Chaos is revered by others, he is viewed as an annoyance to Victor's boss and close friend, J.J. McClure ([[Burt Reynolds]]). Because of this, Victor is expressly forbidden to speak the name of Captain Chaos in J.J.'s presence, hence the reason Victor always cautiously refers to the hero simply as ''"...Him."'' (usually followed by a twinge of magical music).
Near the beginning of the [[Cannonball Run (film)|first film]], Victor makes mention of "...Him", but audiences are briefly left wondering who Victor is talking about until he and J.J. crash their test race car after being stopped at a police road block; when one of the cops asks who they think they are, Victor, in cape and cowl, emerges from the passenger side and introduces himself for the first time as Captain Chaos while J.J., whom he introduces as his "faithful companion, [[Kato (The Green Hornet)|Kato]]", sits in embarrassment in the driver's seat.
Near the film's end, J.J.'s disdain for Captain Chaos boils over after he loses the race, and J.J. angrily rips the cape and cowl off of Victor's person, but Victor almost immediately dons a new alter ego he names "Captain USA", whose cape and cowl are similar, only blue in color, spangled with white stars and with "USA" embroidered onto the cowl's forehead.
In the [[Cannonball Run II|sequel film]], J.J. is more tolerant of the good Captain when he shows up during a fight with the mafia.
==Abilities== Captain Chaos' "powers" include: *'''Increased strength and endurance''', fueled by rushes of adrenaline when Victor feels threatened. *'''Fearlessness'''; Captain Chaos will jump into the middle of any melee with fists and feet flying, effortlessly subduing any and all of his opponents, standing with arms akimbo and laughing in hearty triumph amid his enemies' defeat. *'''Expert driving skills''', which are at least known to veteran racer and Cannonball opponent Jamie Blake ([[Dean Martin]]), who derisively refers to Victor as "The Blimp", but then warns his partner Morris Fenderbaum ([[Sammy Davis Jr.]]), "When he puts on that mask, he'll blow your goddamn doors off!"
==Origin== In the first film, when Pamela ([[Farrah Fawcett]]) asks Victor how he came to know Captain Chaos, Victor explains:
{{cquote|When I was real young, I didn't have any friends like I do now, like J.J., and... well, like J.J. One day, I was in the schoolyard, nine guys were beatin' me up pretty good, and there he was. ''Dun dun DUNNN!''...out of the blue! ''Pow! Slam! Bam! Baff!'' I sure was grateful. Nobody bothered me at school after that.}}
==Filmography== The character of Captain Chaos as portrayed by Dom DeLuise has appeared in ''[[The Cannonball Run]]'' (1981), ''[[Cannonball Run II]]'' (1984), and his alter ego, Victor Prinzim, appeared (in doll form) in the ''[[Robot Chicken]]'' episode "Gold Dust Gasoline" (2005), voiced by DeLuise.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robot Chicken Season 1 Episode 3 - "Gold Dust Gasoline"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TYSKOd3MHWs|work="Death Race"|publisher=16 September 2011}}</ref>
==Notes== In the initial screenplay draft, the alter-ego of Captain Chaos was termed "Rahul." <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1KI5tFG32uI</ref>
[[Washington Redskins]]' tight end [[Chris Cooley (American football)|Chris Cooley]] (2004-2012), was given the nickname "Captain Chaos" by his teammates. This nickname was created when teammates bet him he would not go out to the opening coin toss and introduce himself to the opposing team captains as "Captain Chaos". He did, and the nickname stuck.

{{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Chris Garland | image = | caption = | fullname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|4|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bristol]], England | death_date = | height = {{height|ft=5|in=10}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | youthyears1 = 1964–1966| youthclubs1 = [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | years1 = 1966–1971 | clubs1 = [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | caps1 = 143 | goals1 = 31 | years2 = 1971–1974 | clubs2 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps2 = 92 | goals2 = 22 | years3 = 1974–1976 | clubs3 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | caps3 = 55 | goals3 = 15 | years4 = 1976–1983 | clubs4 = [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | caps4 = 64 | goals4 = 11 | years5 = 1981 | clubs5 = → [[Västerås SK Fotboll|Västerås SK]] (loan)| caps5 = 13 | goals5 = 4 | years6 = 1982 | clubs6 = Caroline Hill | caps6 = | goals6 = | years7 = | clubs7 = [[Gloucester City A.F.C.|Gloucester City]] | caps7 = | goals7 = |totalcaps = 367+|totalgoals = 83+ | manageryears1 = | managerclubs1 = [[Minehead A.F.C.|Minehead]] | nationalyears1 = 1970| nationalteam1 = [[England national under-23 football team|England U23]]| nationalcaps1 = 1| nationalgoals1 = 0 }} '''Christopher Garland''' (born 24 April 1949) is an [[English people|English]] former [[association football|footballer]] who played in all four divisions of [[the Football League]].<ref name=NB>{{cite web |url=http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player/chrisgarland.html |title=Chris Garland |work=UK A–Z Transfers |publisher=Neil Brown |accessdate=13 November 2009}}</ref> He was [[cap (sport)|capped]] once by [[England national under-23 football team|England at under-23 level]].
A [[forward (association football)|forward]], he began his professional career with local club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in April 1966. He was sold to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for £100,000 in 1971, and went on to play on the losing side of the [[1972 Football League Cup Final|1972]] [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] final. He joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 1974, before returning to Bristol City in November 1976. The club underwent a dramatic decline from the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] to the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] and he had to accept a termination of his contract for half the amount due in 1982, though he went on to remain at the club for another season. He later played for [[Gloucester City A.F.C.|Gloucester City]], coached at [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] and managed [[Minehead A.F.C.|Minehead]].
==Playing career==
===Bristol City=== Garland was born on 24 April 1949 in [[Ashton Gate, Bristol]], England, the second son of Grace and George William Henry, a factory worker and lorry driver respectively.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=1}}</ref> He attended a trial for England Schoolboys, and was signed up as an apprentice at [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in 1964.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=8}}</ref> However, he broke his leg in a park kick-around with friends, and was severely reprimanded by manager [[Fred Ford (footballer)|Fred Ford]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=10}}</ref> He recovered and went on to sign professional terms with the club five days after his 17th birthday.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=17}}</ref> He made his [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] debut at [[Ashton Gate Stadium]] on 3 December 1966, in a 2–0 victory over [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=22}}</ref> This was his only appearance of the [[1966–67 Football League|1966–67]] season, and the "Robins" went on to finish in 15th place.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=23}}</ref>
Ford was sacked early in the [[1967–68 Football League|1967–68]] campaign, and caretaker-manager [[Les Bardsley]] made wholesale changes to the first eleven, including a recall for Garland.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=24}}</ref> He played all three of Bardsley's games in charge, and scored in the 3–3 draw with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=25}}</ref> He started in new manager [[Alan Dicks]]'s second game in charge, and remained a first team regular throughout the rest of the season, scoring nine goals in 32 league and cup games.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=27}}</ref> In the [[FA Cup]] the club beat [[Bristol derby]] rivals [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] and [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], before losing 2–0 to [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in a bad tempered game that saw [[Gary Sprake]] sent off for punching Garland in the jaw.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=30}}</ref>
He formed an effective strike partnership with big target man [[John Galley]] in the [[1968–69 Football League|1968–69]] and [[1969–70 Football League|1969–70]] seasons, and was linked with moves away to bigger clubs.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=33}}</ref> On 8 April 1970, Garland won his only international [[cap (sport)|cap]], for [[England national under-23 football team|England under-23]] in a 4–1 win over [[Bulgaria national under-21 football team|Bulgaria]] at [[Home Park]]; he was a substitute for [[Paul Edwards (footballer, born 1947)|Paul Edwards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-u23-intres-det.html |title=England – U-23 International Results- Details |first=Barrie |last=Courtney |publisher=RSSSF |accessdate=13 November 2009 |date=27 March 2004}}</ref> City finished in 19th place in the [[1970–71 Football League|1970–71]] season, four points above the relegation zone.
===Chelsea=== Garland was sold to [[Dave Sexton]]'s [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for £100,000 in September 1971.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=38}}</ref> He was signed as a squad player and found first team opportunities limited, especially after spending a month out injured following a bad tackle from [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]'s [[Barry Lyons (footballer)|Barry Lyon]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=42}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in his fifth appearance, in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] semi-final win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]; he also scored in the second leg.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=44}}</ref> He went on to sing with the rest of the team in ''[[Blue Is the Colour (song)|Blue Is the Colour]]'', a song to coincide with [[1972 Football League Cup Final|the final]], which went on to reach number five in the charts.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=47}}</ref> He played in the final at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]], in which Chelsea lost 2–1 to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=50}}</ref> The "Pensioners" finished the [[1971–72 Football League|1971–72]] campaign seventh in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]].
He finished as the club's joint top-scorer (with [[Peter Osgood]]) in the [[1972–73 Football League|1972–73]] season with 11 goals, but Chelsea dropped to 12th in the league.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=57}}</ref> The [[1973–74 Football League|1973–74]] campaign was worse for the club, as star players like Osgood, [[Alan Hudson]] and [[David Webb (footballer)|David Webb]] and management fell out, and they dropped to 17th place in the league.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=59}}</ref> Sexton was sacked in October 1974, and his replacement [[Ron Suart]] only lasted until April. New boss [[Eddie McCreadie]] allowed Garland to leave the club after receiving bids from Leicester City and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] that matched the fee Chelsea had paid for Garland.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=61}}</ref> In total he scored 31 goals in 114 league and cup appearances for Chelsea.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theblues.chelseafc.com/cgi-bin/playersearch.pl?Chris%20GARLAND |title=Chris Garland |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |accessdate=13 November 2009}}</ref> Chelsea declined in the immediate aftermath of his departure, and suffered relegation at the end of the [[1974–75 Football League|1974–75]] season.
===Leicester City=== Garland was sold to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for £100,000 in 1974; he agreed to join the club without speaking to Everton as he was convinced by manager [[Jimmy Bloomfield]] that Leicester were the right club for him.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=62}}</ref> He scored eight goals in ten matches, including a hat-trick in a 3–2 win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] at [[Filbert Street]] on 22 March, to help the "Foxes" to finish three points above the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] relegation zone at the end of the [[1974–75 Leicester City F.C. season|1974–75]] season.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=65}}</ref> He was one of three regular rotated forwards in the [[1975–76 Leicester City F.C. season|1975–76]] campaign, alongside [[Frank Worthington]] and [[Bob Lee (footballer)|Bob Lee]], and City went on to finish seventh; he claimed another hat-trick in a 3–0 [[FA Cup]] victory over [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 3 January.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=66}}</ref> He scored three goals at the start of the [[1976–77 Leicester City F.C. season|1976–77]] season, but broke [[Jeff Blockley]]'s cheekbone after punching him during training for what Garland believed was Blockley's rough treatment of the club's apprentices.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=68}}</ref> Garland placed four transfer requests, and was eventually sold back to his hometown club.<ref name="page 69">{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=69}}</ref>
===Return to Bristol City=== Garland was sold to his former club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] for a £110,000 fee in November 1976; during his absence the club had reached the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] while still under the stewardship of [[Alan Dicks]].<ref name="page 69"/> Dicks planned to use Garland in a strike partnership with target man [[Paul Cheesley]], but a severe injury to Cheesley meant that Garland had to play as the target man centre-forward despite his small stature.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=74}}</ref> He initially struggled in the role, but Dicks had no other suitable replacements other than [[Tom Ritchie]], who also was not a natural centre-forward.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=75}}</ref> Despite a tough end-of-season schedule City managed to pick up enough to points to narrowly avoid relegation in [[1976–77 Football League|1976–77]], with Garland scoring winning goals against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=77}}</ref>
He tore his cruciate ligaments early in the [[1977–78 Football League|1977–78]] season and missed not only the rest of the campaign but also spent much of the [[1978–79 Bristol City F.C. season|1978–79]] and [[1979–80 Football League|1979–80]] seasons struggling with the same injury.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=88}}</ref> Dicks departed following relegation in 1979–80, and under [[Bob Houghton]]'s stewardship they dropped immediately out of the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] in the [[1980–81 Football League|1980–81]] campaign, with Garland again having limited involvement due to his knee and ligament injuries.<ref name="page 89">{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=89}}</ref> Houghton sent him on loan to [[Västerås SK Fotboll|Västerås SK]] of the [[Swedish Football Division 2|Swedish second Division]] to help him gain fitness.<ref name="page 89"/> There he scored the winning goal against local rivals [[IFK Västerås]], and helped the club to a third-place finish in [[1981 Swedish football Division 2|1981]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=90}}</ref>
He rarely featured under Houghton, and when new manager [[Roy Hodgson]] arrived he informed Garland and seven teammates ([[Julian Marshall (footballer)|Julian Marshall]], [[Jimmy Mann (footballer)|Jimmy Mann]], [[Geoff Merrick]], [[Peter Aitken]], [[David Rodgers]], [[Trevor Tainton]] and [[Gerry Sweeney]]), known as the "Ashton Gate Eight", that would have to take [[voluntary redundancy]] as part of a last-ditch plan to save the club, which was on the verge of folding; Garland agreed and lost £3,750.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=92}}</ref> He and Merrick then spent six months playing in [[Hong Kong]] for Caroline Hill.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=94}}</ref> City suffered a third successive relegation in [[1981–82 Football League|1981–82]] after dropping out of the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]]. After relegation to the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]], Garland would go on to be re-employed by Bristol City manager [[Terry Cooper (footballer, born 1944)|Terry Cooper]] for the [[1982–83 Football League|1982–83]] season, playing as a non-contract player until February 1983, when he retired.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=96}}</ref>
==Later life== After retiring, he spent two years selling fruit and vegetables [[door-to-door]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=97}}</ref> He also featured in the [[Southern Football League|Southern League]] for [[Gloucester City A.F.C.|Gloucester City]], before returning to professional football as a coach at [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=98}}</ref> During his time there he got his friend [[Ian Botham]] to play for the club and Yeovil won admission into [[the Football League]].<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=99}}</ref> However his business was failing and he developed gambling and drinking problems and was contemplating suicide at one stage.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=100}}</ref> He entered the [[wine]] distribution business but again his business failed and he was declared [[Bankruptcy|bankrupt]].<ref name="page 101">{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=101}}</ref> He went on to work as a [[bookmaker]]'s clerk, which only worsened his gambling addiction.<ref name="page 101"/> He later spent time as manager of [[Western Football League|Western League]] side [[Minehead A.F.C.|Minehead]] whilst working as an [[insurance]] salesman.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=102}}</ref> He was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Chris Garland Interview|url=https://thefoxfanzine.wordpress.com/2009/10/02/the-chris-garland-interview/|website=thefoxfanzine|accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref>
He married Patricia Cooper in June 1970.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=34}}</ref> They had two sons, Adam and Ryan, and one daughter, Jessica.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=43}}</ref> The couple split after 25 years of marriage.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=109}}</ref> After leaving Patricia he spent time sleeping rough, before he was housed by a property developer who also provided him with casual work.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=110}}</ref> A testimonial with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] raised £81,000 for Garland, which he split between himself and his ex-wife.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=111}}</ref> He married again, to Ruth, in 2004.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=113}}</ref> However his gambling problems remained, and he was again declared bankrupt a few years later.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=114}}</ref> However, with funding from the [[Professional Footballers' Association]] (PFA) he was able to undergo pioneering surgery to help relieve his Parkinson's.<ref>{{harvnb|Garland|2008|p=116}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Chrysta Bell |background = solo_singer |image = Chrysta_Bell_performing_in_London,_June_2017.jpg |caption = Chrysta Bell performing in London, 2017. |image_size = |alias = |birth_date = |birth_name = Chrysta Bell Zucht |birth_place = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], United States |origin = |genre = {{flatlist| *[[Dream pop]] *[[Pop music|pop]] }} |occupation = {{flatlist| *[[Singer]] *songwriter *model }} |instrument = {{flatlist| * [[singing|Vocals]] * [[guitar]] }} |label = {{flatlist| *Meta Hari *La Rose Noire *QQ5 }} |website = {{URL|chrystabell.com}} }}
'''Chrysta Bell Zucht''',<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wolfson|first1=Todd|title=Chrysta Bell Zucht is one of my longest running muses|url=http://toddvwolfson.tumblr.com/post/176464481/chrysta-bell-zucht-is-one-of-my-longest-running|website=Todd Wolfson Music Photography|accessdate=September 21, 2014|date=August 31, 2009}}</ref><ref name="mysanantonio.com">{{cite web|last1=Saldana|first1=Hector|title='Musical chemistry' with David Lynch helps songbird Chrysta Bell find her voice|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/entertainment/music/article/Musical-chemistry-with-David-Lynch-helps-2191676.php|website=My San Antonio|accessdate=September 21, 2014|date=September 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=|first1=|title=Former owner Dr. A.D. Zucht and his daughter Chrysta Bell Zucht.|url=http://www.chron.com/news/local/gallery/Inn-on-the-Riverwalk-86995/photo-6390674.php|website=Chron.com|accessdate=September 21, 2014|date=June 2, 2014}}</ref> (known as '''Chrysta Bell''') is an American singer, songwriter, model, and actress from [[Texas]].{{r|born}} She has worked professionally with filmmaker and composer [[David Lynch]] since the pair met in 1999 and together they released two albums in the genre of [[dream pop]]. Her voice and musical style are described as “ethereal” and “sensual”.<ref name="blogs.wsj.com">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2016/10/26/what-its-like-to-make-music-with-david-lynch/ |title=What It’s Like to Make Music With David Lynch - Speakeasy - WSJ |publisher=Blogs.wsj.com |date=October 26, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/2017/01/video-chrysta-bell-david-lynch-beat-the-beat/ |title=Video: Chrysta Bell & David Lynch – "Beat the Beat" |publisher=SPIN |date=January 25, 2017 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> Her new album, ''We Dissolve'', released independently on Meta Hari Records in June 2017, is produced by [[John Parish]], with guests including [[Adrian Utley]], [[Geoff Downes]] and [[Stephen O'Malley]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Calvario |first=Liz |url=https://lavidaliz.com/2017/03/04/chrysta-bells-forthcoming-album-we-dissolve-has-a-release-date/ |title=Chrysta Bell’s Forthcoming Album ‘We Dissolve’ Has A Release Date |publisher=La Vida Liz |date=March 4, 2017 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> In her first television acting role, Chrysta Bell plays FBI Agent Tammy Preston in the [[Twin Peaks (2017 TV series)|revival]] of ''[[Twin Peaks]]'' that premiered on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] on May 21, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael Nordine |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/10/david-lynch-chrysta-bell-twin-peaks-1201740996/ |title=David Lynch’s Musical Collaborator Chrysta Bell on ‘Twin Peaks’ |publisher=IndieWire |date=October 27, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== Chrysta Bell's mother is also a professional singer, whom she credits for early exposure to music from [[Michael Jackson]], [[Eurythmics]] and [[The Go-Gos]], among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iconvsicon.com/2011/09/26/chrysta-bell-discusses-her-new-collaborative-album-with-david-lynch/ |title=Chrysta Bell Discusses Her New Collaborative Album With David Lynch |publisher=Icon vs. Icon |date=September 29, 2011 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref><ref name="popbitez.net">{{cite web|last1=Hopkins|first1=Scott|title=Chrysta Bell: Confessions of a Dark Temptress|url=http://popbitez.net/2011/11/11/chrysta-bell-scott-hopkins-pop-bitez/|website= Pop bitez|accessdate=January 25, 2016|date=November 11, 2011}}</ref> Chrysta Bell started her professional singing career at a young age as a session vocalist in a [[recording studio]] owned by her parents in her hometown of [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Weinstein|first1=Amy|title=Awakening: The musical partnership between Chrysta Bell and David Lynch|url=http://fillermagazine.com/culture/music/music-news-interviews-the-musical-partnership-between-chrysta-bell-and-david-lynch/|website=Filler Magazine|accessdate=January 25, 2016|date=September 3, 2015}}</ref>
==Career== After attending high school in San Antonio,<ref name="mysanantonio.com"/> Bell moved to [[Austin]], [[Texas]], and became the lead singer for [[8½ Souvenirs]].<ref name="popbitez.net"/> The band was named for the [[Federico Fellini]] film [[8½]] and notable for its [[Django Reinhardt]] and [[gypsy jazz]] influence as well as a repertoire of songs with lyrics in French, Italian, Spanish and English.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dierssen |first=Heidi |url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/music/8-1-2-souvenirs-6358327 |title=8½ Souvenirs |publisher=Miami New Times |date=August 5, 1999 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfweekly.com/music/hear-this-74/ |title=Hear This - By |publisher=SF Weekly |date=July 29, 1998 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> In 1997 8½ Souvenirs signed to the [[RCA Records|RCA Victor]] label <ref name="popbitez.net"/> and subsequently released two albums “Happy Feet”(1998) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/release/happy-feet-mr0000054973 |title=Happy Feet - 8½ Souvenirs | Release Info |publisher=AllMusic |date=June 30, 1998 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> and “Twisted Desire”(1999). The band received some national attention after making an appearance on an ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' broadcast in April 1998.<ref>[http://www.tv.com/austin-city-limits/boz-scaggs-followed-by-8-1-2-souvenirs/episode/1124725/summary.html Boz Scaggs followed by 8½ Souvenirs] Retrieved January 25, 2016</ref> That same year they performed as the opening act on an 8-week tour with [[The Brian Setzer Orchestra]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynebraskan.com/the-brian-setzer-orchestra-to-swing-into-omaha/article_7dd32217-05eb-526b-bf81-e1b56cf2b04a.html |title=The Brian Setzer Orchestra to swing into Omaha |publisher=dailynebraskan.com |date=November 30, 1998 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref>
In 1999 Chrysta Bell met [[Creative Artists Agency|CAA]] Agent Brian Loucks <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/entertainment/music/article/Musical-chemistry-with-David-Lynch-helps-2191676.php |title='Musical chemistry' with David Lynch helps songbird Chrysta Bell find her voice - San Antonio Express-News |publisher=Mysanantonio.com |date=September 28, 2011 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref><ref name="vogue.it">{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/magazine/fashion-stories/2013/02/chrysta-bell-by-emma-summerton |title=Chrysta Bell |publisher=Vogue.it |date=February 13, 2013 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> who had the idea that [[David Lynch]] might want to work with her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://davidlynch.livejournal.com/366875.html |title=Dugpa.com Exclusive Interview with Chrysta Bell on "This Train" with David Lynch - David Lynch Community |publisher=Davidlynch.livejournal.com |date=October 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> Loucks arranged a meeting at Lynch's recording studio and the pair “hit it off”, writing their first song together that day.<ref name="blogs.wsj.com"/>
===Musical Collaboration with David Lynch===
Lynch included the song “Polish Poem", co-written with Chrysta Bell, in the final minutes of his 2006 film ''[[Inland Empire (film)|Inland Empire]]''.<ref name="pitchfork.com">{{cite web|author=Matthew Strauss |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/67416-david-lynch-and-chrysta-bell-team-up-for-new-ep/ |title=David Lynch and Chrysta Bell Team Up for New EP |publisher=Pitchfork |date=August 9, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2011, she released a debut solo album ''This Train'', which was co-written and produced by Lynch and released independently through La Rose Noire Records. The album was officially re-released throughout Europe with additional bonus material on January 31, 2014, through the German-based label, QQ5.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/david-lynch-presents-new-muse-chrysta-bell-in-l-a-20120803 |author=Steve Appleford |title=David Lynch Presents New Muse Chrysta Bell in L.A. |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=August 3, 2012 |accessdate=January 13, 2014 |archivedate=August 4, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804035053/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/david-lynch-presents-new-muse-chrysta-bell-in-l-a-20120803 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Singer-Chrysta-Bell-joins-David-Lynch-for-wild-CD-2303834.php |author=Hector Saldaña |title=Singer Chrysta Bell joins David Lynch for wild CD |work=[[San Antonio Express-News]] |date=September 28, 2011 |accessdate=February 24, 2014 |archivedate=March 2, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302044750/http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Singer-Chrysta-Bell-joins-David-Lynch-for-wild-CD-2303834.php |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The pair teamed up again for a 5 – song EP ''Somewhere In The Nowhere'', also produced and co-written by Lynch,<ref name="pitchfork.com"/> released in Oct 2016 on Meta Hari Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://welcometotwinpeaks.com/music/chrysta-bell-david-lynch-night-ride-video/ |title=Chrysta Bell & David Lynch's Rockabilly Trap Stormer "Night Ride" Gets Badass Video |publisher=Welcometotwinpeaks.com |date= |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref>
Along with [[Duran Duran]], [[Lykke Li]], [[Karen O]], [[Moby]], [[The Flaming Lips]], [[Sky Ferreira]], [[Zola Jesus]], [[Donovan]] and [[Angelo Badalamenti]], Chrysta Bell appears on the double LP "The Music of David Lynch",<ref>{{cite web|last=Blistein |first=Jon |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/karen-o-wayne-coyne-duran-duran-set-for-david-lynch-tribute-album-20160407 |title=Karen O, Wayne Coyne, Duran Duran Set for David Lynch Tribute Album |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=April 7, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> performing “Swing With Me”, a song she wrote with Lynch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nerdist.com/the-music-of-david-lynch-is-a-must-have-live-covers-record-review/ |title=THE MUSIC OF DAVID LYNCH is a Must-Have Live Covers Record (Review) |publisher=Nerdist |date=October 17, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> The album is a live recording of a tribute concert<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/david-lynch-1194573 |title=Legendary David Lynch tribute concert gets album release |publisher=Nme.com |date=April 7, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> that took place on April 1, 2015, at the historic Ace Theater in Downtown Los Angeles as a benefit for the [[David Lynch Foundation]]. The concert was filmed for television as well and subsequently aired on [[AXS TV]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Seth Kelley |url=https://variety.com/2015/scene/vpage/david-lynch-tribute-features-duran-duran-flaming-lips-lykke-li-1201465363/ |title=David Lynch Tribute Features Duran Duran, Flaming Lips, Lykke Li |publisher=Variety |date=April 2, 2015 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> The companion book for the concert, "Beyond the Beyond: Music From the Films of David Lynch", includes an interview with Chrysta Bell on her artistic relationship with Lynch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2016/08/09/david-lynch-to-produce-new-chrysta-bell-ep/ |title=David Lynch muse Chrysta Bell readies Somewhere in the Nowhere EP |publisher=Factmag.com |date=August 9, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref>
Lynch has said of Chrysta Bell “The first time I saw her perform, I thought she was like an alien. The most beautiful alien ever.” <ref>{{cite web|author=Vikram Murthi |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/08/david-lynch-chrysta-bell-ep-somewhere-in-the-nowhere-twin-peaks-1201714930/ |title=David Lynch & Chrysta Bell Collaborate On New EP |publisher=IndieWire |date=August 9, 2016 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref>
===Modeling===
Photographer Emma Summerton shot Chrysta Bell for an 8-page feature in the February 2013 issue of [[Vogue Italia]].<ref name="vogue.it"/> In May 2014 [[The Red Bulletin]] Magazine published an interview and pictorial on her titled “A Real Femme Fatale”.<ref>{{cite web|author=Text: Arno RaffeinerPhotography: Aaron Feaver |url=https://www.redbulletin.com/int/en/culture/chrysta-bell-a-real-femme-fatale |title=Chrysta Bell - A real femme fatale |publisher=Redbulletin.com |date=January 1, 1970 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> She appeared on the cover of photographer [[Larry Fink (photographer)|Larry Fink]]'s 2006 book "Somewhere There's Music".<ref>{{cite web|title=Somewhere there's music|url=https://www.damianieditore.com/en-US/product/41|website=Damianieditore.com}}</ref>
===Acting===
Chrysta Bell has appeared in the Chinese film ''[[Once Upon a Time in China and America]]'' (1997) opposite [[Jet Li]] (for which she was credited under her birth name, Chrysta Bell Zucht), the ABC Family reality television series ''[[Switched!]]'' (2004), and a commercial for the [[Ford Motor Company]].<ref name="habit">{{cite web|date=June 2010|accessdate=September 26, 2014|title= Chrysta Bell's Habit|url=http://calendar.denverpost.com/austin_tx/events/show/125224725-chrysta-bells-habit|work=Denver Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chrysta Bell Zucht|url=http://www.hkcinemagic.com/en/people.asp?id=7859|website=Hong Kong Cinemagic|accessdate=September 26, 2014}}</ref> She plays FBI Agent Tammy Preston in ''[[Twin Peaks (2017 TV series)|Twin Peaks: The Return]]'', which premiered on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] on May 21, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sho.com/twin-peaks|author=Showtime|title=25 Years Later the Story Continues|work=[[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]|date=April 25, 2016|accessdate=July 5, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Twin Peaks Will Return on May 21 With a Two-Hour Premiere|author=Dessem, Matthew|date=January 9, 2017|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2017/01/09/twin_peaks_will_return_on_may_21_with_a_two_hour_premiere.html}}</ref>
==Personal life== Chrysta Bell practices [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] and believes in [[reincarnation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Chrysta Bell: A Multidisciplinary Artist |url=http://dailymetal.eu/blog/chrysta-bell--a-multidisciplinary-artist/690/ |accessdate=June 30, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QioVpTos?url=http://dailymetal.eu/blog/chrysta-bell--a-multidisciplinary-artist/690/ |archivedate=June 30, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Raffeiner, Arno|title=A Real Femme Fatale|date=May 2014|url=https://www.redbulletin.com/us/us/culture/chrysta-bell|work=[[The Red Bulletin]]}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name= David Bruce Bleak |birth_date= 27 February 1932 |death_date= 23 March 2006 (aged 74) |birth_place= [[Idaho Falls, Idaho]] |death_place= [[Arco, Idaho]] |placeofburial=[[Butte County, Idaho]] ([[cenotaph]]) |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image= DavidBleak.jpg |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= [[United States|United States of America]] |branch= [[United States Army]] |serviceyears= 1950 – 1953 |rank= [[Staff Sergeant#United States|Staff Sergeant]] |commands= |unit= 2nd Battalion, [[223rd Infantry Regiment (United States)|223rd Infantry Regiment]], [[40th Infantry Division (United States)|40th Infantry Division]] |battles= [[Korean War]] |awards= [[Medal of Honor]]
[[Purple Heart]] }} '''David Bruce Bleak''' (27 February 1932 – 23 March 2006) was a [[soldier]] of the [[United States Army]] during the [[Korean War]]. Bleak rose to the rank of [[staff sergeant]] and was awarded the [[Medal of Honor]], the highest military decoration of the [[United States]], for his actions near [[Minari-gol]], [[South Korea]], on 14 June 1952. Born in [[Idaho]], Bleak dropped out of school to become a [[combat medic]], and was deployed to Korea with the [[US 40th Infantry Division|40th Infantry Division]]. During a mission north into [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] territory, Bleak's patrol came under heavy attack from fortified Chinese positions. Despite being wounded himself, Bleak rushed the Chinese troops multiple times and killed five of them—four using only his hands—before assisting the wounded, and shielding another soldier from a grenade blast. Bleak is credited with saving the patrol's wounded and ensuring that all of its members returned to allied lines. For these actions, he was awarded the Medal of Honor. In the years preceding and following his military service, Bleak worked numerous jobs around Idaho and [[Wyoming]], working as a [[rancher]], [[dairy farmer]], [[truck driver]], and [[meat cutter]] before retiring as a [[radioactive waste]] technician at the [[Idaho National Engineering Laboratory]]. He died in 2006 from [[emphysema]], [[Parkinson's Disease]], and complications from a [[hip fracture]]. == Early life == David Bruce Bleak was born on 27 February 1932 to William Bleak and Tamar Bleak (née Young) in [[Idaho Falls, Idaho]], a remote farming community. The seventh of nine children, he dropped out of high school and worked for a time as a farmer and a [[rancher]] and also for [[railroad]]s, but he grew dissatisfied with life in Idaho.{{harvnb|Collier|Del Calzo|2006|p=151}} He eventually decided to enlist in the [[US Army]], hoping to see the world. Bleak grew to a height of {{convert|6.5|ft}} tall and weighed {{convert|250|lb}}.{{harvnb|Willibanks|2011|p=25}} He was described as humble and quiet throughout his life. Bleak was a member of the [[Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]. == Military service == Bleak entered the Army on 1 November 1950, and attended [[basic combat training]] at [[Fort Riley, Kansas]]. Here, he was selected for [[Army Medical Department (United States)|medical duty]]. After the completion of his training, Bleak was assigned to a medical [[company (military)|company]] attached to the [[223rd Infantry Regiment (United States)|223rd Infantry Regiment]], [[US 40th Infantry Division|40th Infantry Division]] of the [[California Army National Guard]]. Shortly after Bleak was assigned to the unit, it was selected for deployment to the [[Korean War]]. He was moved to [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Camp Cooke]] in [[Lompoc, California]], for advanced medical training in preparation for his deployment. The 40th Infantry Division shipped out to Korea in January 1952, and shortly thereafter, Bleak was promoted to [[sergeant]]. His unit was assigned to a mountainous area near [[Minari-gol]], [[South Korea]], along the [[38th Parallel north|38th Parallel]]. By that point in the war, the fronts had largely stabilized, and the duty in the area was characterized by constant, low-level [[trench warfare]]{{harvnb|Willibanks|2011|p=26}} and continued battles over the same ground which produced high casualties.{{harvnb|Ecker|2004|p=136}} Bleak served as a [[field medic]], assisting troops on the front lines instead of in [[Mobile Army Surgical Hospital]] units.{{harvnb|Greenwood|2005|p=126}} === Medal of Honor action === On 14 June 1952, Bleak was part of a patrol of the 2nd Battalion, 223rd Infantry, sent north to probe [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] forward positions and attempt to capture Chinese soldiers for interrogation. Bleak volunteered to accompany the 20-man patrol of an [[I&R Platoon]] on this mission, which was to send them to a sparsely vegetated feature called Hill 499, where Chinese forces were known to be operating. The patrol left [[United Nations]] lines at 04:30 [[Korea Standard Time]] on 14 June, under cover of darkness. It was preceded by an attack by F Company, 223rd Infantry, to the west which was intended as a distraction.The F Company diversionary attack may have been the action for which [[Corporal]] [[Clifton T. Speicher]] was himself awarded the Medal of Honor. ({{harvnb|Ecker|2004|p=138}}) However, as the patrol ascended the hill, it came under heavy Chinese [[automatic weapons]] fire which struck the lead elements, injuring several soldiers. Bleak, at the rear of the formation, rushed forward and treated and stabilized several soldiers hit in the initial volley, then followed the remainder of the patrol as it continued its mission. As they attempted to continue up the hill, several Chinese soldiers from a nearby trench opened fire, injuring another soldier. According to eyewitness reports, Bleak rushed the trench and dove into it, tackling one Chinese soldier and breaking the man's neck with only his hands, killing him. Bleak was then confronted by a second soldier, whom he reportedly grabbed by the neck, fatally crushing his windpipe. A third Chinese soldier then approached, and in the ensuing scuffle, Bleak used his [[combat knife]] to kill him. Bleak then returned to the patrol and attempted to treat more wounded members, but soon thereafter a Chinese [[hand grenade]] bounced off the helmet of the soldier standing next to him and landed nearby. Bleak tackled the soldier and covered him with his larger frame to protect him from the grenade, but neither was injured in the ensuing blast. The patrol then continued on its mission and was successful in capturing several Chinese prisoners.{{harvnb|Willibanks|2011|p=27}} However, as it descended Hill 499 to return to UN lines, they were ambushed by another group of Chinese hidden in a trench with an automatic weapon. Three soldiers were wounded in the attack, and as Bleak attempted to run to them, he was hit in the leg. Bleak dressed all four wounds, but one of the men was so badly wounded he could not move. In spite of continued Chinese fire and his own injury, Bleak [[Fireman's carry|picked up the wounded soldier]] and began to carry him down the hill. As he attempted to withdraw with the wounded soldier, Bleak was confronted by two more Chinese. Putting down the soldier, Bleak reportedly surprised the Chinese soldiers by charging them and smashing their heads together with such force that he may have [[fracture]]d the skulls of one or both of the assailants before pushing them out of his way.{{harvnb|Ecker|2004|p=138}} Eventually, all 20 men of the patrol returned to the UN lines, but a third of them were wounded. Bleak was credited with saving the patrol, both by promptly treating the wounded and by aggressively attacking and killing or neutralizing five Chinese soldiers. Bleak reportedly suffered nerve damage as a result of his leg wound. His wounds required hospitalization, but he returned to duty on 9 July 1952. His tour in Korea ended shortly after the event. He finished his enlistment by serving in [[Japan]], and on 27 October 1953 he was awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] in a ceremony at the [[White House]] with President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]. He retired from the Army as a [[staff sergeant]]. == Civilian life == After leaving the military at the end of the Korean War, Bleak returned to Idaho. He later moved to [[Wyoming]], where he took various jobs as a [[truck driver]], a [[grocery store]] [[meat cutter]], and a rancher. He eventually married and had four children with his wife, Lois Pickett Bleak. in 1966, he moved to [[Moore, Idaho]], where he ran a [[dairy farm]] for 10 years. He eventually became a janitor at the [[Idaho National Engineering Laboratory]], where he worked his way up until his retirement in the mid-1990s as chief hot cell technician, responsible for disposing of [[Radioactive waste|spent nuclear fuel rods]]. He died on 23 March 2006, at the Lost Rivers District Hospital in [[Arco, Idaho]],{{citation|last=Bernstein |first=Adam |title=David Bleak, 74; Won Medal of Honor in Korea |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/mar/31/local/me-bleak31 |date=31 March 2006 |accessdate=18 March 2012 |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''}} from [[emphysema]], [[Parkinson's Disease]], and complications from a [[hip fracture]]. He died the same day as another Medal of Honor recipient, [[Desmond Doss]]. At the time of his death, he had nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. His body was [[cremated]] and his remains were scattered in Idaho, at his favorite [[fishing]] location. His family later placed a [[cenotaph]] in his honor at the Lost River Cemetery in [[Butte County, Idaho]].{{citation|url=http://museum.mil.idaho.gov/Moh.html |title=Idaho's Medal of Honor recipients |publisher=[[Idaho Military History Museum]] |accessdate=18 March 2012}} ==Honors== In 1995 a medical clinic at [[Fort Sill, Oklahoma]], was named for Bleak, and following his death, the [[Governor of Oklahoma]] declared 14 June 2007 "Sergeant David Bruce Bleak Day" for the 55th anniversary of Bleak's accomplishments. On 14 June 2006, Bleak's family presented his Medal of Honor to the [[Idaho Military History Museum]], where it is now displayed, alongside that of fellow Idaho recipient [[Gurdon H. Barter]]. == Awards and decorations == Bleak's awards include:

However, he was one of only two-the other being [[William R. Charette]]-for whom the decoration was not [[posthumous recognition|posthumous]]. Those recognized after their deaths were [[Richard G. Wilson]] and [[Bryant E. Womack]] from the Army, and [[Edward C. Benfold]], [[Richard Dewert]], [[Francis C. Hammond]], and [[John E. Kilmer]] from the US Navy.{{harvnb|Greenwood|2005|p=131}} [[File:cmoh army.jpg|left|50px]] {{Quotation|Sgt. Bleak, a member of the medical company, distinguished himself by conspicuous gallantry and indomitable courage above and beyond the call of duty in action against the enemy. As a medical aidman, he volunteered to accompany a reconnaissance patrol committed to engage the enemy and capture a prisoner for interrogation. Forging up the rugged slope of the key terrain, the group was subjected to intense automatic weapons and small arms fire and suffered several casualties. After administering to the wounded, he continued to advance with the patrol. Nearing the [[military crest]] of the hill, while attempting to cross the fire-swept area to attend the wounded, he came under hostile fire from a small group of the enemy concealed in a trench. Entering the trench he closed with the enemy, killed 2 with bare hands and a third with his trench knife. Moving from the emplacement, he saw a concussion grenade fall in front of a companion and, quickly shifting his position, shielded the man from the impact of the blast. Later, while ministering to the wounded, he was struck by a hostile bullet but, despite the wound, he undertook to evacuate a wounded comrade. As he moved down the hill with his heavy burden, he was attacked by 2 enemy soldiers with fixed bayonets. Closing with the aggressors, he grabbed them and smacked their heads together, then carried his helpless comrade down the hill to safety. Sgt. Bleak's dauntless courage and intrepid actions reflect utmost credit upon himself and are in keeping with the honored traditions of the military service.{{harvnb|Ecker|2004|p=137}}}} == See also == [[Winnie Davin]] (mother) | awards = President of the British Association for Chinese Studies | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Delia Davin''' (9 June 1944 – 13 October 2016) was a writer and lecturer on [[China|Chinese]] society and particularly Chinese women's stories.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/16/delia-davin-obituary|title=Delia Davin obituary|last=Gittings|first=John|date=16 October 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=18 October 2016}} She was one of the first foreign scholars to consider the impact of the policies of the [[Communist Party of China|Chinese Communist Party]] on women. From 1988 until her retirement in 2004, Davin taught Chinese history at [[Leeds University]], where she became a chaired professor. She was also head of the Department of East Asian Studies and deputy head of the School of Modern Languages and Cultures. Before going to [[Leeds]], she had taught in the Department of Economics and Related Studies at the [[University of York]], where she was a founding member of York’s Centre for Women's Studies. The [[British Association for Chinese Studies]] elected her president for 1993–1994,[http://bacsuk.org.uk/about-us/past-presidents Past Presidents] [http://bacsuk.org.uk/ British Association for Chinese Studies] and the China Panel of the [[British Academy]] made her a member, as did the Executive Council of the Universities’ China Committee in London. == Early life == Davin was born in [[Oxford]], [[England]], to an expatriate literary family of [[Irish people|Irish]] descent who had emigrated from [[New Zealand]]. Her father [[Dan Davin]] was an editor at the [[Clarendon Press]] and her mother [[Winnie Davin]] (née Gonley) was an editor at [[Oxford University Press]]. Davin left school at the age of 15 and finished her high school studies through evening classes. In 1963, aged 19, she went to [[Beijing]] with a group of foreign experts and taught English at the [[Beijing Broadcasting Institute]] until 1965.{{Cite news|url=http://u.osu.edu/mclc/2016/10/17/delia-davin-1944-2016/|title=Delia Davin (1944–2016)|date=17 October 2016|newspaper=MCLC Resource Center|language=en-US|access-date=18 October 2016}} She described her students there in a letter home as "very serious about their work but [having] a gaiety which saves them from being priggish." Her friend, the China specialist [[John Gittings]], later remarked that her contact with these students, many of whom came from working class backgrounds, "gave Davin an intuitive understanding of the Chinese that would enrich her long academic career" and that at this time she already showed "a mature sensitivity for the contradictions of revolutionary China."{{sfnb|Gittings|2016| }} She then returned to England and enrolled at the [[University of Leeds]], where she completed a B.A. degree in 1968 and a Ph.D. degree in 1974 in the Department of Chinese. While a student, Davin visited [[Paris]] and [[Hong Kong]] on research trips. In 1975, Davin returned to China and worked as a translator for the [[Foreign Languages Press]], a position arranged for her by her friends [[Gladys Yang]] and [[Yang Xianyi]], who were also translators. ==Communist policy and women's lives== Davin was one of the first scholars to study [[Chinese Communist Party]] policies on women and the problems of working them out in practice. Her first major work was ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China'' (1976), which she published after returning from her second stay in Beijing. The scholar [[Gail Hershatter]] called the work "classic". She explained that the book followed policies from the 1930s until 1949, but spent the most time and detailed analysis on the 1950s. Chapters treated the Women’s Federation, marriage reform, the effects of land reform and collectivization on women, and the lives of urban women. Davin, Hershatter continued, acknowledged the great changes brought about by the new "Party-state", and described the contradictions between the reformist Marriage Law and the realities of its results; women in the countryside were also caught between economic independence and their continued fixed place in [[patrilocal]] families. The book, said Hershatter, "effectively laid out an agenda for much of the subsequent scholarship on women in the Mao years".{{sfnb|Hershatter|2016}} John Gittings wrote that the book went "far beyond the stereotypes offered both by the communist regime and its critics" and that it probed the "tensions between a new '[[socialism|socialist]]' emphasis on women’s participation in economic and political life and a relatively unchallenged structure of gender and generational relationships in the family."{{sfnb|Gittings|2016}} During the following years, Davin wrote articles and chapters that analyzed marriage migration, domestic service, and [[welfare]] entitlements for Chinese women workers. Her jointly edited book ''China’s One Child Family Policy'' (1985) was one of the first studies of the early effects of that policy. {{sfnb|Hershatter|2016}} The review in ''[[The China Journal]]'' called the essays, though written when the policy was relatively new, "a timely review of the policy's origins, problems, and prospects."Quanhe Yang , "China's One-Child Family Policy (review)," ''The Australian Journal of Chinese Affairs'' 16 (July 1986): 139–141. DOI: 10.2307/2158783 In 1999, after tracking the changes of the post-Mao economic reforms, Davin published a second major study, ''Internal Migration in Contemporary China'', that used field research, interviews, and published media. She remarked that her own parents' "stories of the migration of their parents and grandparents from the west of [[Ireland]] to New Zealand gave me an interest in the forces that drive people to leave their homes and families in search of a living elsewhere, and a sympathy with the struggles and sufferings of migrants everywhere."{{sfnb|Davin|1999| p = xii}} Dorothy Solinger in [[China Quarterly]] wrote that the book was "more for the initiate than for the specialist," but "rich with observations and covers every major topic that touches on internal geographical movement in China since the late 1970s," including the demographic traits of the migrants, state policies, the reason farmers leave the countryside and to come to the city, and the images of these migrants in the media. Although Solinger found "carelessness" and a tendency to rely on "vague words" such "few" and "in general," she found that "overall this volume stands as an excellent summation ... and is filled with insightful comments, if not encased within an overarching framework."Dorothy Solinger "[Review]" ''China Quarterly'' 163 (2000), pp. 850–53 JSTOR: https://www.jstor.org/stable/655807 Davin's interests in women's lives extended to other fields. Her 1992 article, "British Women Missionaries in Nineteenth Century China" examined women whose lives were supposed to take place only in home and family. It looked at their China careers, their effect as role models, and their own conservative views of what their influence should be.{{sfnb|Davin|1992| p = abstract}} ==Studies of Mao Zedong== [[Mao Zedong]] was another long term focus of research and thought. The senior Mao scholar [[Stuart Schram]] both praised and criticized her 1997 biography, noting that Davin's target audience was those "without a prior knowledge of Chinese affairs". He said that writers of brief studies like hers often assume that "because the reader belongs to the uninitiated, he or she is also a semi-literate and write in basic English," or authors may take space limitations "as a pretext not merely for simplifying controversial issues, but for presenting only one side of them." Davin, however avoids both of these temptations: "she writes clearly, evoking the complexity of events and Mao's response to them without hiding her own views."Stuart Schram, (1998)."Review", ''The China Quarterly'' (154), pp. 413–414. https://www.jstor.org/stable/655898 (Accessed 18 October 2016) Schram then added that the book's greatest weakness was its treatment of the [[Yan'an]] period of Mao's career, in which Davin did not mention the single most important theme, that unlike the International Faction, who had parroted the Marxist dogma they learned in the [[Soviet Union]], Mao had "creatively developed [[Marxism]] in the context of Chinese history and culture." By contrast, Schram continued, the chapters on Mao as the ruler of China "deal subtly but forcefully with all the major issues." She puts blame where blame is due: Mao bears a heavy responsibility for one of the great disasters in human history" (p. 69) and the Cultural Revolution claimed victim after victim, leaving Mao "heavily reliant on sycophants and incompetents as he himself grew older and less competent." (p. 77) Schram p. 414. In 2013, Davin published a short biography ''Mao'' (Oxford University Press, ''Very Short Introduction Series''; 2013) John Gittings wrote that the book "rejected current appraisals of Mao as no more than 'a Chinese [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]] with a taste for killing', while recognising that his flawed and contradictory character brought great harm to China..."{{sfnb|Gittings|2016}} The scholar Gregor Benton commented that sometimes "resisting a jumbo-history doesn't necessarily produce a compelling focus and can lapse at worst into patronizing simplification," but that in this case "a broader picture remains unremittingly central, though not at a cost of nuance and some speculative reflection." Gregor Benton, "''[http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/677118 Mao: A Very Short Introduction]'', by Delia Davin," ''The China Journal'', no. 72 (July 2014) DOI: 10.1086/677118 == Personal life == Davin was married three times – first to [[William John Francis Jenner| William (Bill) John Francis Jenner]], a fellow scholar of China; then to Andrew (Andy) Morgan; and finally in 1997 to Owen Wells, a probation officer. She had three children and three step-children. She died of [[cancer]] at home in Ilkley on 13 October 2016, aged 72.{{sfnb|Hershatter|2016}} ==Selected works== ;Books * ''[https://global.oup.com/academic/product/mao-a-very-short-introduction-9780199588664?cc=us&lang=en&# Mao: A Very Short Introduction]'' (Oxford University Press, 2013 {{ISBN|9780199588664}}) * {{citation |first = Delia|last = Davin|author-mask = 3 |title = Internal migration in Contemporary China |publisher = London: Macmillan; New York: St. Martin's|year = 1999 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=BnuGDAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |ref = harv }} * {{citation |first = Delia|last = Davin|author-mask = 3 | title = Mao Zedong: A Life |publisher = Sutton; Reprinted History Press 2009 |year =1997 | ref= none}} * {{citation |first = Delia|last = Davin|author-mask = 3| title = Chinese Lives: An Oral History of Contemporary China |others = co-edited with William Jenner|place = New York |publisher = Pantheon; London: Macmillan; reprinted, Penguin (1989) | year = 1988 | ref = none}} * ''China's One Child Family Policy'', (co-editor with E.
